body:
I think this issue is the root cause of the problem

https://github.com/bazil/fuse/issues/280

@justfly1111 can you try building your own rclone with `cmount` support, like this

    make GOTAGS=cmount

You'll need the fuse header files.

Then try using `rclone cmount ....` instead of `rclone mount ...`. That may or may not work but it would be interesting :-)

I can confirm that it works with cmount compilation option:
```
pkg install gmake

git clone https://github.com/rclone/rclone.git
cd rclone/
gmake GOTAGS=cmount

/root/go/bin/rclone cmount gdrive: /mnt/gdrive --allow-other --config /root/.config/rclone/rclone.conf
```

```
freebsd-version -kru
13.1-RELEASE
13.1-RELEASE
13.1-RELEASE
```

```
df -Th /mnt/gdrive/
Filesystem  Type             Size    Used   Avail Capacity  Mounted on
/dev/fuse   fusefs.rclone    1.0P      0B    1.0P     0%    /mnt/gdrive
```
Perhaps I should make `cmount` be the default mount on `FreeBSD`? This would mean that without some trickery the executables on rclone.org wouldn't have mount support.

I just upgraded from 1.59.0 to 1.59.1 and started to get this problem reproducibly:

rclone[25558]: /data/test: Unmounted rclone mount
rclone[25558]: Fatal error: failed to umount FUSE fs: resource temporarily unavailable

The 1.59.0 binary works. cmount is not available in the binary package (or I missed it). This is on FreeBSD 13.1.

Will try to compile with CMOUNT support.
It looks like good progress has been made fixing this upstream: https://bugs.freebsd.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=258056

bazil/fuze no longer compiles under freebsd so I'm going to have to drop support for it from rclone.

However building with `rclone build -tags cmount` will build `rclone cmount` which does work on freebsd. This will also be aliased as `rclone mount` for v1.65 onwards.

Note that the freebsd binaries downloaded from rclone.org won't have `rclone mount` support as we don't have a freebsd build set up in CI and cross compiling with CGO is quite hard. If someone was to set up the cross compiling with CGO then I would merge it!

issue.title: Unable to create FreeBSD helper for fstab mount

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?

In linux, per rclone mount documentation, you simply have to symlink rclone to mount.rclone in order to get it to work with fstab. In FreeBSD the helpers are named mount_helper (in this case, rclone it should be mount_rclone). Unfortunately this does not allow the helper to be called from fstab since it does not detect that it should be in mount helper mode. 

rclone mount <remote> <local> works fine. 

It seems that possibly mount.rclone and rclonefs are explicitly set / hard coded but mount_rclone is not (for FreeBSD)? 

#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)

rclone v1.64.0-DEV

#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (e.g. Windows 7, 64 bit)

freebsd 13.2-release-p4 (64 bit)

#### Which cloud storage system are you using? (e.g. Google Drive)

smb

#### The command you were trying to run (e.g. `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

mount <mountpoint> (derived from /etc/fstab)

#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (e.g. output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

Unfortunately I do not believe there is really anything to log here since FreeBSD does not use the mount.rclone helper and the mount_rclone helper does not work as a helper it just doesn't mount (using fstab). 

<!--- Please keep the note below for others who read your bug report. -->

#### How to use GitHub

* Please use the üëç [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to show that you are affected by the same issue.
* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.
